sen.j: 饅頭（まんじゅう）とは小麦粉などを練って作った皮（生地：きじ）でアズキ餡などの具を包み、蒸した菓子である。
sen.e: Manju is a cake steamed with fillings such as azuki-bean paste wrapped in the cake dough which flour is kneaded into.
Manju is a cake steamed with fillings such as azuki-bean paste wrapped in the cake dough which flour is kneaded into.
Manju is a cake steamed with fillings such as azuki-bean paste wrapped in the cake dough which flour is kneaded into.

sen.j: 和菓子の一種。
sen.e: It is one of the Japanese traditional confectionery.
It is one of the Japanese traditional confectionery.
It is one of the Japanese traditional confectionery.

sen.j: 漢字は「万十」「万頭」「曼頭」などと書くこともある。
sen.e: Manju (饅頭) can be written as "万十", "万頭", or "曼頭" in Chinese characters.
sen.cmt: 比較のため「饅頭」の漢字を追加しました。
sen.e: Manju (饅頭) can be written as "万十", "万頭", or "曼頭" in Chinese characters.
Manju (饅頭) can be written as "万十", "万頭", or "曼頭" in Chinese characters.

sen.j: 日本の饅頭の起源には2つの系統がある。
sen.e: The Japanese manju was originated from two routes.
The Japanese manju originated in two routes.
sen.cmt: 受動態を能動態に変更しました。
sen.e: The Japanese manju originated in two routes.

sen.j: ひとつは1349年に禅宗の僧と一緒に中国から渡来した林浄因と共に入ってきたと言われている。
sen.e: One is that it was introduced to Japan when Join RIN came from China along with Zen monks in 1349.
One is that it was introduced to Japan when Join RIN came from China along with Zen monks in 1349.
One is that it was introduced to Japan when Join RIN came from China along with Zen monks in 1349.

sen.j: その際、禅宗のお茶と一緒に食べる菓子として饅頭を用いる事を考えた。
sen.e: At that time, Rin came up with the idea of serving the manju as a tea cake eaten with tea for Zen Buddhism.
At that time, Rin came up with the idea of serving the manju as a tea cake eaten with tea for Zen Buddhism.
At that time, Rin came up with the idea of serving the manju as a tea cake eaten with tea for Zen Buddhism.

sen.j: しかし従来の饅頭は肉を使ってしまう（本来の仏教では肉食は禁じられていないが、日本では肉食を禁じた）ので、代わりに小豆を使った饅頭が考案されたと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that manju stuffed with azuki bean filling was created because original manju was stuffed with meats (eating meats was prohibited in Japan while not basically prohibited by Buddhism).

It is said that manju stuffed with azuki bean filling was created because original manju was stuffed with meat (eating meat was prohibited in Japan while it was not originally prohibited by Buddhism).
sen.cmt: 複数形を単数形に訂正しました。
sen.e: It is said that manju stuffed with azuki bean filling was created because original manju was stuffed with meat (eating meat was prohibited in Japan while it was not originally prohibited by Buddhism).

sen.j: その後、林は奈良の漢國神社の近くに住居して塩瀬という店を立て評判になった。
sen.e: After that, Rin resided near the Kango-jinja Shrine in Nara and opened a shop called Shiose which gained popularity.
After that, Rin resided near the Kango-jinja Shrine in Nara and opened a shop called Shiose which gained popularity.
After that, Rin resided near the Kango-jinja Shrine in Nara and opened a shop called Shiose which gained popularity.

sen.j: お盆の行事として8月1日は釜の蓋と称し饅頭の日でもある。
sen.e: As an event of the Bon (the Festival of the Dead), August 1st is called a lid of cauldron and is also Manju Day.
As an event of the Bon (the Festival of the Dead), August 1st is called a lid of cauldron and is also Manju Day.
As an event of the Bon (the Festival of the Dead), August 1st is called a lid of cauldron and is also Manju Day.

sen.j: 林浄因は漢國神社境内社の「林神社」に祀られ、製菓業者の信仰を集めている。
sen.e: Join RIN has been enshrined in the Rin-jinja Shrine on the premises of the Kongo-jinja Shrine and worshiped by confectionary makers.
Join RIN has been enshrined in the Rin-jinja Shrine on the premises of the Kongo-jinja Shrine and worshiped by confectionary makers.
Join RIN has been enshrined in the Rin-jinja Shrine on the premises of the Kongo-jinja Shrine and worshiped by confectionary makers.

sen.j: もうひとつの系統は、林が伝えたとされる年より100年ほど遡る1241年に南宋に渡り学を修めた聖一国師が、福岡の博多でその製法を伝えたと言われる。
sen.e: The other route is that Shoichi Kokushi who were educated in Southern Sung introduced manju production techniques in Hakata, Fukuoka Prefecture in 1241, nearly 100 years before Rin introduced it to Japan.

The other route is that Shoichi Kokushi who was educated in Southern Sung introduced manju production techniques in Hakata, Fukuoka Prefecture in 1241, nearly 100 years before Rin introduced it to Japan.
sen.cmt: 単数形の誤りを訂正しました。
sen.e: The other route is that Shoichi Kokushi who was educated in Southern Sung introduced manju production techniques in Hakata, Fukuoka Prefecture in 1241, nearly 100 years before Rin introduced it to Japan.

sen.j: 聖一は辻堂（つじのどう現・博多駅前一丁目）に臨済宗・承天寺を創建し、博多の西、荒津山一帯をたく鉢に回っていた際、いつも親切にしてくれていた茶屋の主人に饅頭の作り方を伝授したと。
sen.e: It is said that Shoichi built the Joten-ji Temple of the Rinzai sect in Tsujinodo (present Hakataekimae 1-chome) and taught a manju recipe to a teahouse owner who was always kind of him when he went around Mt. Aratsu, to the west of Hakata, for takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan).

It is said that Shoichi built the Joten-ji Temple of the Rinzai sect in Tsujinodo (present Hakataekimae 1-chome) and taught a manju recipe to a teahouse owner who was always kind to him when he went around Mt. Aratsu, to the west of Hakata, for takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan).
sen.cmt: 前置詞の誤りを訂正しました。
sen.e: It is said that Shoichi built the Joten-ji Temple of the Rinzai sect in Tsujinodo (present Hakataekimae 1-chome) and taught a manju recipe to a teahouse owner who was always kind to him when he went around Mt. Aratsu, to the west of Hakata, for takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan).

sen.j: このときに茶屋の主人に書いて与えた「御饅頭所」という看板が、今では東京・赤坂の虎屋黒川にある。
sen.e: At that time, he gave the teahouse owner the hand-written signboard saying "omanju dokoro (place to eat manju)", which is now possessed by Toraya Kurokawa in Akasaka, Tokyo.
At that time, he gave the teahouse owner a hand-written signboard saying "omanju dokoro (place to eat manju)", which is now possessed by Toraya Kurokawa in Akasaka, Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 定冠詞を不定冠詞に変更しました。
sen.e: At that time, he gave the teahouse owner a hand-written signboard saying "omanju dokoro (place to eat manju)", which is now possessed by Toraya Kurokawa in Akasaka, Tokyo.

sen.j: 奈良に伝わった饅頭は、ふくらしこ粉を使う「薬饅頭」で、博多のほうは甘酒を使う「酒饅頭」とされる。
sen.e: The manju introduced in Nara refers to "kusuri-manju" using baking powder and the other in Hakata refers to "sake-manju" using amazake (sweet mild sake).
The manju introduced in Nara is "kusuri-manju" using baking powder and the other in Hakata is "sake-manju" using amazake (sweet mild sake).
sen.cmt: refer toをisに変更しました。
sen.e: The manju introduced in Nara is "kusuri-manju" using baking powder and the other in Hakata is "sake-manju" using amazake (sweet mild sake).

sen.j: 日本に定着した後、餡や皮の製法にさまざまな工夫が凝らされ、種々の饅頭が作られるようになった。
sen.e: After the manju took root in Japan, various types of manju was made by exercising various ingenuity in methods of making bean paste and cake dough.
After the manju took root in Japan, various types of manju was made by exercising various ingenuity in methods of making bean paste and cake dough.
After the manju took root in Japan, various types of manju was made by exercising various ingenuity in methods of making bean paste and cake dough.

sen.j: マーラーカオなど従来の饅頭（マントウ）を起源とした中華風の饅頭は、中華まんとして区別されている。
sen.e: Chinese-style buns originated in traditional mantou such as ma lai gao are classified into chuka-man (Chinese steamed bun).
sen.cmt: 「ma lai go」「ma lai koh」「ma lai gao」などいろいろスペルがありましたが、「馬来糕」の北京語読みの「ma lai gao」を選択しました。
sen.e: Chinese-style buns originated in traditional mantou such as ma lai gao are classified into chuka-man (Chinese steamed bun).
Chinese-style buns originated in traditional mantou such as ma lai gao are classified into chuka-man (Chinese steamed bun).

sen.j: なお、現在の中国でマントウといえば、なかに餡も具も入っていない一種の蒸しパンである。
sen.e: In China, present mantou refers to a kind of steamed breads without bean paste or filling in it.
In China, present mantou refers to a kind of steamed breads without bean paste or filling in it.
In China, present mantou refers to a kind of steamed breads without bean paste or filling in it.

sen.j: 中に具が入っているものは包子（パオズ b?ozi）と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Buns stuffed with fillings are called bao zi.
Buns stuffed with fillings are called bao zi.
Buns stuffed with fillings are called bao zi.

sen.j: 饅頭（まんとう）は伝承によれば、3世紀の三国志の蜀の宰相・諸葛亮が孟獲との南征の帰途、川の氾濫を沈めるために川の神へと人身御供を立てて、人の首を川に沈めるという風習を改めさせようと小麦粉で練った皮に羊・豚の肉を詰めそれを人間の頭に見立てて川に投げ込んだところ川の氾濫が静まった故事からこの料理が始まったという説がある。
sen.e: According to the lore, the dish of mantou was originated in the historical fact that a flood subsided after a kneaded flour dough stuffed with mutton and pork to imitate a human head was thrown into a river in order to change the custom of sinking a human head into a river for human sacrifice to stop floods when Zhuge LIANG, the prime minister of Shu in the Sanguo Zhi (History of the Three Kingdoms) was on his way back from southern expedition to attack Meng HUO in the third century.

According to the lore, the dish of mantou originated in the historical fact that a flood subsided after a kneaded flour dough stuffed with mutton and pork, which imitated a human head. was thrown into a river in order to change the custom of sinking a human head into a river for human sacrifice to stop floods when Zhuge LIANG, the prime minister of Shu in the Sanguo Zhi (History of the Three Kingdoms) was on his way back from southern expedition to attack Meng HUO in the third century.
sen.cmt: 受動態を能動態に変更しました。
sen.e: According to the lore, the dish of mantou originated in the historical fact that a flood subsided after a kneaded flour dough stuffed with mutton and pork, which imitated a human head was thrown into a river in order to change the custom of sinking a human head into a river for human sacrifice to stop floods when Zhuge LIANG, the prime minister of Shu in the Sanguo Zhi (History of the Three Kingdoms) was on his way back from southern expedition to attack Meng HUO in the third century.
sen.cmt: 余分なピリオドを削除

sen.j: ただしこの説は北宋時代の高承『zh事物紀原』卷二 酒醴飲食部や曾三異『』などに記事があり、のちの明時代に書かれた説話『三国志演義』に収録され多く知られるようになり、このように解説されることが多い。
sen.e: This story is talked a lot, however, because it is mentioned in books such as the Shurei inshokubu, the Vol. 2 of the "Jibutsukigen (similar books of China)" written by Cheng GAO and the "Yin hua lu (因話録) (Anthology of Essays and Short Stories)" written by Sanyi ZENG (曾三異), and then became well known for the episode in the "Romance of the Three Kingdoms" which was later written during the time of the Ming dynasty.
sen.cmt: ①事物紀原について、サイトを確認すると、原文のzhはありませんでしたので、削除しました。<http://kotobank.jp/word/%E4%BA%8B%E7%89%A9%E7%B4%80%E5%8E%9F>に日本語読みがありましたので、こちらを表記しています。②酒醴飲食部の読み不明③『』の部分は、確認した結果「因話録（Yin hua lu, Anthology of Essays and Short Stories）」でしたが日本語読み不明。<www.springerlink.com/index/83R1870115381L51.pdf>を参考④曾三異の読み方が分かりませんでしたが、北京語のピンインを表記しました。
sen.e: This story is talked a lot, however, because it is mentioned in books such as the Shurei inshokubu, the Vol. 2 of the "Jibutsukigen (similar books of China)" written by Cheng GAO and the "Yin hua lu (因話録) (Anthology of Essays and Short Stories)" written by Sanyi ZENG (曾三異), and then became well known for the episode in the "Romance of the Three Kingdoms" which was later written during the time of the Ming dynasty.

This story is talked a lot, however, because it is mentioned in books such as the Shurei inshokubu, the Vol. 2 of the "Jibutsukigen (similar books of China)" written by Cheng GAO and the "Yin hua lu (因話録) (Anthology of Essays and Short Stories)" written by Sanyi ZENG (曾三異), and then became well known for the episode in the "Romance of the Three Kingdoms" which was later written during the time of the Ming dynasty.

sen.j: ちなみに「神を欺き、本物の頭だと信じ込ませる」ことから「瞞頭」と最初で呼ばれ、発音は同じ"マントウ"である。
sen.e: In fact, it was written as "瞞頭" at first which means to deceive deities to make them believe that is a real human head, pronouncing "mantou" as well.
In fact, it was written as "瞞頭" at first which means to deceive deities to make them believe that is a real human head, pronouncing "mantou" as well.
In fact, it was written as "瞞頭" at first which means to deceive deities to make them believe that is a real human head, pronouncing "mantou" as well.

sen.j: その後、饅頭は川に投げ入れるのももったいないので祭壇で祭った後、食べられる様になったため、饅頭は当初は頭の形を模して大きかったものが、段々小さくなっていったと言われている。
sen.e: Afterward, the mantou was eaten after enshrined at the altar because throwing it into a river was wasteful, and therefore a big mantou imitating a human head got smaller and smaller.
Afterward, the mantou was eaten after enshrined at the altar because throwing it into a river was wasteful, and therefore a big mantou imitating a human head got smaller and smaller.
Afterward, the mantou was eaten after enshrined at the altar because throwing it into a river was wasteful, and therefore a big mantou imitating a human head got smaller and smaller.

sen.j: 一方、中華思想から見た場合、南の部族を南蛮と呼び南蛮人の頭である「蛮頭」説もある。
sen.e: It is also said that it was written as "蛮頭" meaning a head of the Southern barbarian because the Southern tribe was called Southern barbarians in terms of Sinocentrism.
It is also said that it was written as "蛮頭" meaning a head of the Southern barbarian because the Southern tribe was called Southern barbarians in terms of Sinocentrism.

sen.j: 小麦粉、黒砂糖、膨張剤を用いた生地で餡を包んだ饅頭。
sen.e: It is a cake with bean paste filling wrapped in the dough made from flour, brown sugar, and baking powder.
It is a cake with bean paste filling wrapped in the dough made from flour, brown sugar, and baking powder.
It is a cake with bean paste filling wrapped in the dough made from flour, brown sugar, and baking powder.

sen.j: 大島饅頭・温泉饅頭とも。
sen.e: It is also called oshima manju or onsen manju.
It is also called oshima manju or onsen manju.

sen.j: 利休饅頭、薄皮饅頭もこの一種。
sen.e: Rikyu manju and usukawa manju are one of the cha-manju.
Rikyu manju and usukawa manju are one of the cha-manju.

sen.j: 観光地（特に温泉街）でのおやつやお土産にも好んで用いられる。
sen.e: It is popular as a snack and a gift at tourist spots (especially hot spring resorts).
It is popular as a snack and a gift at tourist spots (especially hot spring resorts).

sen.j: 薯蕷饅頭|薯蕷（上用）饅頭 （じょうよまんじゅう）
sen.e: Joyo-manju
Joyo-manju
Joyo-manju

sen.j: すりおろしたヤマノイモの粘りを利用して米粉（薯蕷粉、上新粉）を練り上げ、その生地で餡等を包み、しっとりと蒸し上げた饅頭。
sen.e: It is a moist cake steamed with fillings such as bean paste wrapped in the dough into which rice powder (grated yam powder or finer rice powder) is kneaded with the help of the stickiness of grated yam.

It is a moist cake steamed with fillings such as bean paste wrapped in the dough into which rice powder (grated yam powder or finer rice powder) is kneaded with the help of the stickiness of grated yam.

It is a moist cake steamed with fillings such as bean paste wrapped in the dough into which rice powder (grated yam powder or finer rice powder) is kneaded with the help of the stickiness of grated yam.

sen.j: 使われる山芋にはつくね芋（京都）、大和芋（関東）、伊勢芋（中部地方）などがある。
sen.e: Yam used includes tsukuneimo (Chinese Yam) (Kyoto), yamatoimo (Japanese slimy potato) (Kanto region), and iseimo (Japanese yam) (Chubu region).
Yam used includes tsukuneimo (Chinese Yam) (Kyoto), yamatoimo (Japanese slimy potato) (Kanto region), and iseimo (Japanese yam) (Chubu region).

sen.j: 茶席で使われる主菓子（おもがし）のひとつ。
sen.e: It is one of the omogashi (main sweets) used for tea ceremony.
It is one of the omogashi (main sweets) used for tea ceremony.

sen.j: 奈良時代林浄因が作ったという伝説から、その子孫のお店の名前をとり塩瀬饅頭とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is called Shiose manju from the legend that it was made by Join RIN in the Nara period, taking the name of the shop owned by his offspring.

sen.j: 酒母（酒種、麹に酵母を繁殖させたもの）を使用して小麦粉の生地を発酵させ、中に餡を入れた饅頭。
sen.e: It is a cake with bean paste filling wrapped in the flour dough which is fermented by yeast mash (yeast cultured in rice malt).

sen.j: 「酒饅頭」は長野市、新潟県長岡市ではあんまんのようなものである。

sen.j: 唐饅頭、もみじ饅頭、栗饅頭、千鳥饅頭（福岡県）、乳菓などがこれにあたる。
sen.e: It includes tou manju, Momiji manju, kuri-manju, Chidori manju (Fukuoka), and emulsion.

sen.j: 洋菓子や中華菓子（月餅）の影響を受けて明治時代以降に発達したとされる。
sen.e: Influenced by western confectionery and Chinese sweets (moon cakes), it was developed after the Meiji period.
Influenced by western confectionery and Chinese sweets (moon cakes), it was developed after the Meiji period.

sen.j: オーブンで焼く物（オーブン物）、鉄板で焼く物（平鍋物、平物）などがある。
sen.e: Some manju are baked in an oven (which are called oven mono) and others are baked on a cast-iron pan (which are called hiranabe mono or hira mono).

sen.j: さらにパイ皮やビスケット生地、スコーン生地を用いたより洋菓子に近い物（宮崎県のチーズ饅頭など）がある。

sen.e: Although it generally refers to chuka-man (Chinese steamed bun), in Hokkaido, it refers to a sweet with bean paste filling wrapped in the pancake-like dough (chukadane "中花種" in terms of Japanese traditional confectionery) made from flour, sugar and egg.

sen.e: Although it generally refers to chuka-man (Chinese steamed bun), in Hokkaido, it refers to a sweet with bean paste filling wrapped in the pancake-like dough (chukadane "中花種" in terms of Japanese traditional confectionery) made from flour, sugar and egg.

Although it generally refers to chuka-man (Chinese steamed bun), in Hokkaido, it refers to a sweet with bean paste filling wrapped in the pancake-like dough (chukadane "中花種" in terms of Japanese traditional confectionery) made from flour, sugar and egg.

sen.j: 中花が転じて中華となり、中華まんじゅうと呼ばれるようになったと考えられている。
sen.e: The Chinese characters for chuka, "中花" was changed into "中華" and then the manju started to be called chuka manju.
The Chinese characters for chuka, "中花" was changed into "中華" and then the manju started to be called chuka manju.
